contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[The Honourable]] | name = Norman Augustine Cafik | honorific-suffix = | image = | constituency_MP = [[Ontario (electoral district)|Ontario]] | parliament = Canada | predecessor = [[Michael Starr (politician)|Michael Starr]] | successor = [[Thomas Fennell (politician)|Thomas Fennell]] | term_start = 1968 | term_end = 1979 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1928|12|29}} | birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Canada|Canadian]] | spouse = | party = [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] | relations = | children = | residence = | alma_mater = | occupation = | profession = | cabinet = Minister of State (Multiculturalism) | committees = | portfolio = | religion = | signature = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Norman Augustine Cafik''', [[Queen's Privy Council for Canada|PC]] (born December 29, 1928) is a former [[Canada|Canadian]] politician. Born in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] of a Ukrainian-Polish father and a Scottish-Irish mother,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://speeches.empireclub.org/details.asp?FT=yes&SpeechID=650|title=Multiculturalism, National Unity and the Canadian Economy|date=6 Apr 1978|work=The Empire Club of Canada}}</ref> Cafik was unsuccessful in his attempts to win a [[Legislative seat|seat]] in the [[Canadian House of Commons]] in the [[Canadian federal election, 1962|1962]] and [[Canadian federal election, 1963|1963 election]]s, but was elected as the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) for the [[electoral district (Canada)|riding]] of [[Ontario (electoral district)|Ontario]] in the [[Canadian federal election, 1968|1968 election]].<ref name="Parlbio">{{CanParlbio|ID=7f5ea10f-f4c5-4350-b707-6c6522149e5f|nolist=yes}}</ref> He attempted to move to provincial politics, running in 1973 for the leadership of the [[Ontario Liberal Party]]. He lost on the third ballot of the [[Ontario Liberal leadership conventions|leadership convention]] to [[Robert Nixon (politician)|Robert Nixon]]. In 1977, he was the second person of [[Ukrainian Canadian|Ukrainian]] descent to be appointed to the [[Canadian Cabinet]] when [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Pierre Trudeau]] made him [[Minister of State (Canada)|Minister of State]] for [[Multiculturalism]]. ([[Michael Starr (politician)|Michael Starr]] was appointed by [[John George Diefenbaker]] as the first Ukrainian in Cabinet.) He lost his seat in the House in the [[Canadian federal election, 1979|1979 election]] that defeated the Trudeau government and returned to private life.<ref name="Parlbio"/> ==References== {{reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Cafik, Norman | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Canadian politician | DATE OF BIRTH =December 29, 1928 | PLACE OF BIRTH =[[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cafik, Norman}} [[Category:1928 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Canadian people of Ukrainian descent]] [[Category:Liberal Party of Canada MPs]] [[Category:Members of the House of Commons of Canada from Ontario]] [[Category:Members of the Queen's Privy Council for Canada]] [[Category:People from Toronto]] {{Liberal-Ontario-MP-stub}}
